title: 105_s896
content: The "Landmine Elimination Act of 1997" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings related to landmines. Congress finds that on August 4, 1995, the Senate voted to impose a moratorium on US use of anti-personnel landmines starting in February 1999. Additionally, on April 3, 1996, senior retired US military officers urged the President to ban the production, stockpiling, sale, and use of these landmines, stating it would be humane and militarily responsible. The generals supported a ban on anti-personnel landmines, stating it would be humane and militarily responsible. They emphasized that it would not compromise military effectiveness or safety. In Vietnam, many US military personnel were killed or injured by landmines, and similar casualties occurred in Bosnia among soldiers under UN and NATO command. The Department of State estimates that a person is killed or injured by a landmine every 22 minutes. President Clinton declared the US would aggressively pursue an international agreement to ban anti-personnel landmines. On May 16, 1996, President Clinton declared the US would aggressively pursue an international agreement to ban anti-personnel landmines. On June 7, 1996, the Organization of American States declared the goal of a Western Hemisphere landmine free zone. On June 4, 1997, the Organization of African Unity adopted the goal of establishing Africa as an anti-personnel landmine free zone. On October 5, 1996, Canada announced it would pursue negotiations on a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines. The Organization of African Unity adopted the goal of establishing Africa as an anti-personnel landmine free zone. On December 10, 1996, the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution to pursue a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines. The United States-sponsored resolution aims to pursue a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines, with negotiations set to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The US could use its international influence to secure broad support for the treaty, which would enhance security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines. The United States aims to secure broad support for a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines, which would enhance security and humanitarian interests by deterring their use against US Armed Forces and civilians. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON NEW DEPLOYMENTS OF ANTI-PERSONNEL LANDMINES. Beginning on January 1, 2000, no funds may be used for new deployments of anti-personnel landmines. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days outlining alternative actions for such deployments on the Korean Peninsula. Consultations with experts are required for the report. The President has the authority to delay the restriction if needed. The President may delay the restriction on new deployments of anti-personnel landmines on the Korean Peninsula if he certifies to Congress that they are essential for the defense of South Korea during a war or emergency. Consultations with experts are required for preparing the report. Congress certifying new deployments of anti-personnel landmines on the Korean Peninsula as essential for the defense of South Korea during a war or emergency. The report must detail efforts to implement proposed measures and any additional suggestions from the Secretary of Defense and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "anti-personnel landmine" is defined as a munition designed to detonate by contact with a person, causing harm. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" refer to placing or arming such mines after January 1, 2000. The term "anti-personnel landmine" refers to a munition designed to harm individuals. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" involve placing or arming these mines after January 1, 2000. Command-detonated Claymore munitions are excluded from this definition.
